Caucus day – the day of reckoning for this question. I have been at 0% since the first day, and to be honest, this is beginning to feel more like a reckless wager than a confident forecast. If I lose, I lose it all – although there is an opportunity to mitigate damages with the other caucus questions. Confession, I will be caucusing with the Democrats, and the thought of a Trump candidacy makes me very, very, very, very sad. I’m sure that has something to do with my stance. That said, my main reasoning for 0% has been the lack of Trumps “ground game” throughout the process. I will say listening to the news, reading 3 of the state’s newspapers, and visiting the candidate’s websites, that finding ones caucus is easier and more transparent than it has ever been – and Trump’s is the easiest of any. Type in your address and it tells you where to go. You can print out a simple flyer on “How to Caucus in Iowa” if you need. Other sites have no obvious direct link (Rubio), or they want you to fork over name, email before sharing where to show (Cruz). But without boots on the ground, can Trump get folks to show up? He has probably hired a call center….??? Weather is always cited as a concern. This year, weather is in the 30’s – warm for Iowa (we get hit later). The winter storm will be entering from the SE, arriving sometime between 9 PM and midnight, starting as rain, wintery mix, and turning to snow later on. Looks like it will be missing the SE third of the state almost completely. It will be too late to interfere with the caucuses, and should allow everyone to get out of town wanting to head for New Hampshire and points east. The threat of a blizzard may divert some caucus goers who think a trip to the supermarket is more important than the caucus. The doors close at 7:00 and participants need to be in line by then. All-in-all, it should not greatly effect turnout for those who plan ahead. And then there are the polls. Generally they are still close. Likely voter polls give Trump a greater edge that the “stalwart” polls (those polls that canvass the folks listed as actually voting on a regular basis.) Turnout is key, for Trump. I repeat, can he do it? One of my main concerns is Cruz has appeared to peak, and may not be a second choice.  There are a lot of candidates, and votes could be fragmented. There is still around 50% (question that) of caucus goers who are undecided (http://www.radioiowa.com/2016/01/18/surveying-undecided-iowa-gop-caucus-goers/ ). Who will they decide? Even though the Republican method insures one person one vote, folks don’t like to waste a vote. If a voter shows up thinking Rick Santorum but is the only one, will they vote for Rick, or break for Cruz? Rubio? Trump? Possibly be swayed by a few Ben Carsons? After rereading this, maybe I will just go and hibernate for the winter – to heck with the caucus.

It's going to be a question of who shows up, plain and simple. That's why buzz will be so important tomorrow. You must be a registered Republican to participate, but you can register at your caucus location with proof of address and a valid ID. And, as Ivanka Trump points out in her how-to-caucus video, Republicans will be casting a secret ballot-- once. No need to plan your evening around convincing the neighbors you don't know that well to stand in your candidate's group, and no need to worry about those same folks remembering who you supported if your allegiance might be termed impetuous. This argues for a strong Trump showing, particularly if social media gets cranked up ("Print your cell bill and go! #Showing up for Trump"). Lines of people bearing utility bills aren't likely to be Cruz supporters; his campaign touts a strong [traditional] ground game. With this said, the weather will be a factor locally. Rain and snow will be moving into western Iowa by caucus time. Might that be enough to dampen the enthusiasm of the less well-organized? It probably won't matter in Des Moines and points east, but is enough to keep me under 60%.

Upping from 4% to 8%. I'm torn on this IFP between trying to "shoot the moon" (i.e. stay low), or raise my forecast with the consensus. Every fibre of my being tells me that Iowa can't possibly actually let themselves vote for Donald Trump, but after seeing the DMR poll, I was floored to hear (I was watching the broadcast where they revealed the results) that Trump has support from -- essentially -- all the groups. Selzer then went on to say something to the effect of Trump is right where you'd want to be if you were the front-runner. Support amongst the establishment and support amongst some of the more extreme groups. I still think that he won't win and there are two things that I'm clinging to when holding that opinion: 1) 45% undecided. There are still lots of people who haven't made up their mind, yet, and it's quite possible that they all decide to vote for... Rick Santorum. OK, they probably won't do that, but there is that uncertainty remaining in this IFP that things could still fall in an unexpected manner. However, it's noteworthy that of Trump supporters 71% said that they were "for sure" going to vote for him (highest amongst the GOP candidates, if I recall correctly). So, while the 45% not fall in Trump's favo[u]r, he may still win. 2) Eminent domain. As part of the DMR poll, they asked what bothered you most about candidates and the one for Trump was "eminent domain." Given that there are still 48 hours before this thing is all finished, one of Cruz/Trump might be smart to start hitting Trump for this -- HARD -- and frequently! (http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/article/2581966/)

One one hand, across polls, Trump is consistently ahead of Ted Cruz, but not by an un-overcomeable percentage margin. A factor might work against him is his refusal to participate in the Iowa Debate. Evidence has been found that he took to twitter and, in a poll, asked his followers whether or not he should do the GOP debate. Of his followers, 56% said yes, while 44% said no. If his twitter followers, whom I would assume to be devoted Trump fans, are leaning on the side that he should do the debate, then perhaps his not doing the debate will hurt him more significantly than imagined. In addition, history would show that presidents who skip on the debate are at risk of losing the caucus. However, Trump has also time and time again usurped the precedents of history.

PEW RESEARCH
Interesting report out today from the Pew Research Center suggesting yet another hurdle where Trump seems to buck trends. It's national in scope, but puts an interesting twist on how I've been reading the race between Cruz & Trump. "Being seen as a religious person is generally an asset for candidates; people who think a candidate is a religious person tend to be more likely to see that candidate as a potentially good president. But many Republicans think Trump would be a good president despite his perceived lack of religiousness. Of the 56% of GOP voters who think Trump would be a good or great president, a substantial minority of them (17% of Republican registered voters overall) say they think Trump is not religious. The pattern is very different for the other leading GOP candidates; virtually all Republicans who think Cruz, Rubio and Carson would be successful presidents (and who express a view about their religiousness) also say they view those candidates as at least somewhat religious. 
...
The new survey shows that among religious groups, fully half of white evangelical Protestant voters (including both Republicans and those who identify with the Democratic Party or as political independents) think Trump would make a “good” or a “great” president. Evangelicals – who are among the most reliably Republican religious constituencies in the electorate – express a similar degree of confidence that Carson and Cruz would be successful presidents.
...
While there are about as many evangelicals who think Trump would be a “good” or “great” president as say the same about Cruz and Carson, there also is considerably more wariness about Trump than about Carson or Cruz; three-in-ten evangelicals (29%) say Trump would be a “poor” or “terrible” president, which is roughly twice the share who say this about either Cruz or Carson." Trump's "good/great" assessment of 52% just squeaks by Cruz's 49% on that last quoted paragraph. Report PDF

Followers beware.  This could be completely bogus thinking bubbling up from a swamp of sketchy data.  But here goes.  Until now, I have been heavily influenced by the following ideas:  (1) Iowa is different, (2) Iowa voters are different, (3) the Iowa caucus format is odd, (4) Cruz has a strong connection with a conservative religious block of voters, (4) Cruz's presumed "great ground game" will win the day, (5) Trump's Iowa strategy is slap-dash, (6) People from New York City are not popular in Iowa.  However, I have to admit that Trump seems to be smarter (and tougher) than I am and he may well be a marketing genius.  Marketing is such a tricky business.  Marketing theories seem so simple, but many people underestimate how difficult it is to achieve marketing success.  Trump has done a brilliant job of getting to the front of a crowded field.  He's had to use some wild tactics to do this, but he knew what he was doing at moments when other candidates (like Bush) had no clue.  I now believe that Trump understands Iowa and certain weaknesses in retail distribution that have eluded me.  You can ride a bus through Iowa for weeks.  You can line up precinct chairs all over the place.  That may not matter because Cruz has serious problems with his personal brand and skillful brand management usually crushes door-to-door.  Everyone Cruz has ever worked with, hates him, and voters can now see why.  Trump just slaughtered Cruz when he made his smug "New York Values" attack.  After Trump's rebuttal, the camera focused in on Cruz and he stood revealed as the most unpopular kid in class.  I can no longer ignore the evidence that Trump is winning the branding contest on a national level by a huge margin.  He has the outright poll lead in 24 states and is tied in 7 others.  Is there really something different about Iowa?  Is there something special about the Republican caucus format?   Is the ground game everything in Iowa?  One should note that the Republican caucus rules are not the same as Democratic caucus rules.  Unlike Democrats, Republican caucus goers will not be standing around in groups waiting to be counted.  Republicans have no group viability disqualification process.  Republicans will not be waving at other members of the church choir to recruit them for the next count.  The Republican caucus format is a straight-up secret ballot.  Ground game and precinct organization may have some importance, but I am starting to believe that retail politics won't be as powerful on the Republican side.  Maybe I'm a dope, but I'm betting on the guy who looks like the marketing genius.

To win the caucuses, your supporters have to attend them and stick around and be reasonably coherent or at least persistent.  Statewide polls in a state that runs precinct-level caucuses are at best misleading.  Many people have preferences in or predictions about boxing matches. Somewhat fewer watch the matches on television, especially if something else comes up, unless they feel strongly about it.  A smaller number yet get in their cars, drive to the venue, buy tickets, and watch the match.  Even fewer think it would be fun to work the corner for one of the participants.  Attending a caucus is more like the last of these; answering a poll question is more like the first.   On the bright side if you're a Trumpeter, weather for caucus day is likely to be fairly balmy by Iowa winter standards--for Des Moines and Cedar Rapids, highs in the lower 40s F  (middle 30s F in Sioux City), lows in the low 20s F and probably no big snow in most of the state.  That should somewhat increase attendance among lukewarm supporters of all candidates, but Trump's folks are probably  more tepid (and torpid) than the Texas Twit's. That may bump up Trump's odds a bit, but I don't know enough about the geographic distribution of his precinct-level support to even pretend to know what I'm talking about in any detail.

Ugh. Letting myself be buffeted around by daily poll numbers on this one. Down five points.

This question has become an enormous nail-biter in a landscape of questionable data.  Trump edges back up in the polls, but not beyond the margin of error, and polls are probably less accurate than they used to be.  Cruz is said to gain traction with a particular type of Iowa conservative religious voter thought to be more likely to turn out on caucus night, but how can one be sure about that?  There may even be a chance that one of the laggards will determine the result.  What if Rubio surges just enough to lower the size of the plurality needed to win?  Will that help Trump or Cruz?  This question is like the famous Iowa "loose meat" sandwich.  When you try to eat it, half of it ends up in your lap.

If others falter, their support goes to someone besides Trump. https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/01/11/3-very-real-warning-signs-for-donald-trump-in-iowa/

http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/elections/presidential/caucus/2016/01/13/iowa-poll-cruz-holds-3-point-lead-trump-attacks/78684344/
"Ted Cruz sits atop the Republican pack in Iowa with just 19 days until the caucuses, but Donald Trump is just 3 percentage points behind, a new Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics Iowa Poll shows.
Over the last month, Cruz’s poll numbers have taken a 6-point hit as he confronts the crucible of being Iowa’s GOP front-runner, under attack from the Trump bazooka and the ethanol industry. But likely caucusgoers' opinions of the ultraconservative Texas U.S. senator remain sky high (76 percent view him favorably).
...
In third place with likely GOP caucusgoers is Marco Rubio, with 12 percent, and Ben Carson is huddled close behind at 11 percent. Those are precarious perches, because a majority of their supporters say they could still be persuaded to support someone else, said Iowa Poll pollster J. Ann Selzer.
...
A majority of likely caucusgoers, 56 percent, could change their minds about their first-place choice or still do not have a first choice, the poll finds.
...
The Iowa Poll of 500 likely Republican caucusgoers was conducted Jan. 7-10 by Selzer & Co. of Des Moines. The margin of error is plus or minus 4.4 percentage points.
...
While Cruz's lead of 10 percentage points on Trump in early December has whittled to 3 points, underlying data show Cruz to be well-positioned. The constitutional lawyer is the second-choice pick for more voters than any other candidate. And he attracts almost half the electorate when percentages of first- and second-choice preferences are combined, Selzer noted.
...
Cruz may be boxed in tactically when it comes to attacks: 75 percent of likely caucusgoers view his decision generally to avoid criticizing Trump as a favorable trait." http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/elections/presidential/caucus/2016/01/13/8-talking-points-new-iowa-poll-gop-caucus-race/78695088/ "Among caucusgoers overall who say their minds are made up, the race goes to Trump with 34 percent, Cruz at 30 percent and Carson at 10 percent. All others are in single digits, Selzer said.
...
A majority of Cruz’s supporters (56 percent) like his opposition to the Renewable Fuel Standard.
...
Among the overall caucus electorate, a 42 percent plurality don’t like his stance, and 37 percent find it attractive.
Far more of a problem are Cruz's votes to cut the military and his lack of foreign policy experience.
...
Cruz has more potential for growing his support than anyone else in the race, including Trump. Cruz is second choice of almost half of Trump supporters (47 percent), Selzer said. The reverse isn’t true for Trump: Only 25 percent of Cruz backers pick Trump second. Among those who voted for Romney in 2012, a plurality are now with Cruz (26 percent). Trump is next (22 percent), pretty much mirroring the overall horse race numbers, Selzer said. And Cruz leads Trump by the highest margins with some of the caucuses’ most faithful voters: very conservative voters, seniors, tea party supporters, evangelical conservatives and churchgoers, and residents of Iowa’s 4th Congressional District, which is represented by U.S. Rep. Steve King, who endowed his endorsement on Cruz in November." (disclaimer: I have Cruz at 55% to become the nominee)

Ran across some interesting HuffingtonPost/YouGov survey results that speak to some things I raised in my previous forecast and that underscore @clinton 's response. My original forecast here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/89558 (links to survey results at the bottom of this forecast) Birtherism Poll
Q1 – On Voting Action - Nearly 1/3 were unsure whether they would actually vote for a party-nominated candidate if they were well-qualified yet born outside the U.S.  Republicans had fewer that were unsure (probably influenced by the current conversation), but the Midwest was just above overall results. – Seems to be a hefty swing vote there. Q2 – On Obama’s Birthplace - The Midwest skewed highest in the belief that Obama was not born in the U.S. and Republicans polled highest in that belief (53%) – no surprises here. Q3 – On Cruz Eligibility – Overall majority view Cruz as eligible. Republicans’ high response in the affirmative (70%) drives the overall up. Republicans exhibit the least uncertainty one way or another (17%) as regards eligibility. And while the Midwest has the least uncertainty among census regions as to his eligibility (20%), it scores only third in the affirmative (57%), and first in the negative (22%).  – this gets underneath the question of Republican acceptance of a birther charge leveled against one of their own, yet from Q1 they may not be as certain about actually voting for him (at least as a proxy as in Q1) Q4 – Cruz/Trump Believability – Most believe Cruz’s assertions as to his eligibility over Trump, but Republicans and the Midwest region believe Trump more than their other demographic counterparts (i.e. democrats, indies, South, West). Fair number still unsure who to believe (29%) Q5 – Trump Belief v Trump Attack – The majority believe Trump is just on the attack rather than espousing any sort of genuine belief. Professor Tribe at Harvard (both teacher and mentor for Obama and Cruz) has indicated that the Supreme Court has not taken this question up and that their is considerable murkiness with regard to the legal interpretation of this question.   Media reports indicates willingness among democrats to seek a ruling through the judicial system were Cruz to be selected as the nominee for the Republican Party.  Tribe has indicated, contra Cruz, that his status (as a potential president) is not as clear as Cruz claims.   These two dynamics could have considerable influence on the outcomes of primary in Iowa. Recent polls put Trump and Cruz in an approximate tie. Trump supporters are enthusiastic while Cruz may seem uninspiring to some Iowans. Trump is making a push now in Iowa with more ads, appearances, etc. As a result, I'm slightly raising my probability estimate that Trump will win Iowa.

Cruz moved early and has a more established base in Iowa. In addition, Iowa's population is apparently conservative with 15% age 65 and older and a significant percentage of born again Christians. These factors lead me to believe that Cruz will have a more solid emotional connection with caucus voters who will show up and vote. I think Trump will do better than one might expect because he's hired a strong manager and is now taking the process seriously. My prediction is that Cruz will win by a slim margin.

I see a lot people wishing, hoping and praying that Trump won't win Iowa (or indeed the Presidency). Unfortunately for those people, Trump rises week after week, with his supporters being the most likely to support him unwaveringly.

There's definitely reason to doubt whether Trump can turn his consistently good (but not spectacular) polling into votes - especially given the singularities of the Iowa caucus system. This will certainly warrant revisiting slightly closer to the caucuses, however.

Now is about when you need to start checking the weather forecasts. Caucus turnout, especially among rookies, is heavily weather dependent. We've had a remarkably mild winter so far in the Upper Midwest-- a few cool snaps and more rain than snow-- which facilitates retail campaigning and has probably kept a few struggling candidates in the mix. Gov. Huckabee, for example, completed the Iowa Long March today (http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/elections/presidential/caucus/2016/01/07/mike-huckabee-99th-county-campaign-iowa-caucus/78281080/). His timing was excellent; the season's first Arctic Blast is forecast to commence on Saturday. The Register's campaign tracker listed 25 Huckabee events between January 2 and now, second only to the 28 Sen. Cruz planned between January 4 and 9. Clearly, both men consider Iowa vital to their future success. But will either be able to quickly lock up a room come caucus night? Evangelical participants-- the target audience for both-- have several self-identified candidates from which to choose, and will see them regularly in the next two weeks: Cruz, Huckabee, Dr. Carson (13 events listed between January 6 and 11) and Sen. Santorum (11 events listed between January 7 and 12). Supporters may work long and hard to come to a consensus on February 1st.  Restraint appears to be a common theme among more "secular" candidates, though they have hardly conceded the get-to-know-you field (with the possible exception of Govs. Gilmore and Christiem who had no scheduled events as of today). The former CEO of HP just scheduled six events next week. Gov. Kasich had one on the 4th, while Sen. Rubio had five between January 4 and 6. Gov. Bush has four listed on January 12-13, and Sen. Paul-- by far the most ambitious of this group-- is on a 10 event spree today and tomorrow. Their events, too, are high-touch, the most remote being a town hall. Again, caucus participants will be asked to winnow. But, if I may be so bold as to surmise that these will be the so-called "establishment" Republicans, their process will also be orderly. They've been through this before.  And then we have The Donald. He doesn't hold "meet and greets." He headlines rallies (two are upcoming) and sells campaign paraphernalia. He excites, or incites, depending on your point of view, people who have drifted away from the political process or did not participate in the first place. They may not be savvy, and they may not know where to go on caucus night (JeanP's comments are insightful in this regard), but they are fired up. And his campaign, more than any other, gives them permission to vent their frustrations. He says what some of them want to say, but don't... in public. He struts. He pouts. He interrupts himself with ever more out-there statements. In Bad Boy parlance, he's Mick Jagger in a suit (with apologies to Sir Mick.) I may be proven wrong, but I still give him a 25% shot at winning, and a greater chance at coming in second. As a Minnesotan, I've seen what a "screw it" candidate can do. Gov. Ventura won because a wave of non-voters took advantage of same-day registration in an election featuring two of the least exciting "normal" candidates in recent memory. Yes, voting is quicker and easier than caucusing. But you still have to find your polling place, bring the right ID to register, and stand in line to do it.

One of the cool tools I was trained on was SCAN (Scientific Content Analysis). In short, this technique is used to obtain information and detect deception from statements of witnesses or suspects (or most Presidential candidates).
While there are skeptics to the effectiveness of this technique, I am a strong supporter of it. In investigations and compliance assessments, I found that, deployed properly and coupled with other interrogation processes, it yielded good results. I know of at least one former FBI counter-terrorism officer that would agree.
For those forecasters interested in knowing more about this technique, check out this site: http://www.lsiscan.com/
LSI, Laboratory for Scientific Interrogation. SCAN was developed by Avinoam Sapir, former chief polygraph examiner for the Israeli police in Jerusalem (several in my group suspected that he also worked for the Mossad, which he neither confirmed nor denied when asked).

I might be digging myself into a hole here, but reaffirming my long standing 0%. I will be attending the caucus on the Democratic side. Granted, the Democrats are more complicated -- not to mention more fun -- but even so, the caucus is a process.  In the previously posted "Donald Trump’s Strongest Support" ( http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/31/upshot/donald-trumps-strongest-supporters-a-certain-kind-of-democrat.html?_r=0 ) is that Iowa isn't full of ardent Trump supporters. The second thing is the lack of political savvy. I have worked with these guys, and have had them as neighbors. We have engaged in political discussion. The one thing I have noticed is that even though they are registered to vote, they don't. (That last statement is based upon some post election polling, and also checking on the voter rolls. When getting out the vote, I have checked to see when the last time neighbors have voted, and am amazed how many do not.) And this is in the general elections -- caucuses are a higher bar. First, precincts are not necessarily the normal polling place. If new to the process, it is best to have someone tell you when and where to show up. And if you are late, the doors are closed and you don't get in. Once you are in, you have to stick around for awhile for the vote. There is a social component to the caucus, which is why the evangelical voters turn out. And why would these folks need someone to tell them when and where to show up? I'll just point to this: http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/dec/18/republican-voters-bomb-agrabah-disney-aladdin-donald-trump

When faced with multiple choices, none of which are well differentiated, people go with the person/entity they know.  Trump's TV presence trumps his policies.  Absent an issue appearing that differentiated the candidates and allows other candidates to become known, Trump wins.  Or if the menu had fewer choices (Trump vs. 1 or 2) then Trump would have a larger issue.  The size of the field (number of choices) and lack of differentiating factors (explainable to the masses) leads to an irrationally rational choice based on familiarity.  This is essentially the same phenomenon that gives us multiple Bush / Clinton presidencies.

I had to get my initial emotional reaction which was I bloody well hope not. Then I moved to the view that in a multi horse race you should very rarely place an even money bet (although a couple of previous races argue against that) so I made my first position a 30% chance of winning and then looked for reasons to adjust that number.
I was influenced by the Politico story showing a significant majority of GOP insiders thought Trump would win Nevada , New Hampshire and South Carolina but the same survey with the same methodology showed Trump behind in Iowa (http://www.politico.com/story/2015/11/politico-caucus-donald-trump-iowa-2016-polling-216227) . So I adjusted my number downwards by 10%. It seems like people are finally coming to a view that Trump is not going to implode by himself (http://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2015/12/07/anti-trump-effort-launches-super-pac/) and some serious money may be coming to the table to battle with him. That adjusted his chances down. I estimated 4% The Monmouth poll (http://www.monmouth.edu/assets/0/32212254770/32212254991/32212254992/32212254994/32212254995/30064771087/de240398-df23-47b6-8470-91977d38b749.pdf) on Iowa as opposed to National polls shows Cruz gaining and Carson tanking with Rubio also gaining. In politics momentum is important and it seems that although Carson is falling away numbers are not moving to Trump. There appears to be some sort of ceiling to Trumps support in Iowa which may mean that if the vote solidifies he will not gain much but other candidates will. This seems to be also reflected in the RCP Poll average data which I would rely on more than individual polls (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/ia/iowa_republican_presidential_caucus-3194.html). However I felt that information was reinforcing my other adjustments rather than adding to them.
Given the nature of the Iowa caucuses are different than the others (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iowa_caucuses) involve a large percentage of evangelicals, and require a much stronger local organisation that discounted Trumps chances against Cruz in Iowa although that factors play out differently in other states. Again this reinforced other information but dropped my estimate by a further 5% I then looked at what would happen if a candidate imploded. Given that Trump has been given every chance to implode and has not done so I discounted that likelihood. I also looked at the possibility that Trump went out as an independent but concluded that was already in the numbers as he would only do so if he felt his chances of the Republican nomination was gone. Given my comments above about ceilings on votes and the way the Carson votes seem to be moving I had the view that if Rubio or Carson imploded further it would assist Cruz while if Cruz imploded it would assist Rubio more. However the chances of that happening seem low at this phase of the contest so I adjusted my number down by 2% only Finally prediction markets are pricing Trump at 26c versus Cruz at 67 cents (https://www.evernote.com/Home.action#n=da093a12-d1da-4fe6-a504-d051518b47d6&b=145fb819-ade8-4e45-982f-a788b61c2bff&ses=4&sh=1&sds=5&) That adjuted my number upwards by 2% because it was a higher figure than my assessment All that resulted in 11%

http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/ia/iowa_republican_presidential_caucus-3194.html  After reading the DMR/Bloomberg poll, I think there are some positives for Trump.  Obviously, this is a great poll for Cruz, but what matters is whether Cruz can maintain the lead.  I am not ready to rule out Trump winning at this point. Some thoughts about the poll and why Trump should not panic (yet): 1.  The sample may not accurately represent those who will participate in the Iowa caucus. Does this poll represent new people Trump is bringing in?  On the other hand, how reliable is a potential caucus goer Trump’s people signed up in a Walmart parking lot?  Still, the sample may be skewed against Trump but this is a factor we will not know until the Caucus.   2.   Trump’s favorable/unfavorable ratings have remained relatively steady since August.  His favorable rating is 57%, down from 59% in October, and 61% in August.  His unfavorable rating is 38%, one up from October’s 37, and three up from August poll’s 35%.   His negatives have not skyrocketed in spite of numerous inflammatory statements. 3.  The % who chose Trump as their first choice for President:  December: 21%; October: 19%; August 23%.  The % who chose Trump as their second choice for President:   December: 14%; October: 9%; August 9%.  These numbers show an improvement since October. 4.  Trump and Cruz have similar numbers for strength of support.  “Mind is made up” option:  Cruz-43% and Trump 45%. In October, the numbers were 37 and 32, respectively.   Both candidates have 55% of supporters who say they could still be persuaded to support another candidate as their first choice.   5.  17% said “never” to supporting Ted Cruz.  30% said “never” to Donald Trump.  Oddly, Trump’s “nevers” are lower than those for Huckabee and Santorum. 6.  The question:  All other things being equal , which of the following is a more attractive candidate for president at this time:  
19% -- A governor, who has worked with a legislature and who has been responsible for balancing a budget

39% --A government outsider who has handled complex issues and managed teams.
12% -- Not sure. 7.  Comparing Carson, Cruz, Rubio, and Trump:  “Knows the most about how to get things done.”  Trump leads with 49%.  “Would be best at handling the economy” and “Would do the most to solve the illegal immigration problem.”  Trump leads with 50%.  On all three, Trump leads by at least 20%.  On the question of who has the best chance of beating Hillary Clinton, Trump leads with30%. In general, the sort of Iowans who show up for a caucus and stay to the end are not knuckle-dragging hicks, and even the other occupants of the clown car are getting slightly less cowardly about this guy. No matter how he polls now, enough people still have to show up of a frequently-snowy evening willing to subsist on Ritz crackers and Cheez Whiz and prepared to settle in for several hours of both debate and bombast. And there have to be enough of these folks at a lot of caucuses--there are over 1,500 precinct ones, followed by 99 county conventions.  Among other things, this means that statewide poll numbers are a nonsense. The party Poo-bahs have a lot of influence in the caucuses, since when the dust settles they will still control the local party patronage and other jobs, and the party regulars who will attend the caucuses know this.  The local machinery will grind out somebody else, as the Anyone-But movement accelerates. There are pockets of Trumpery everywhere, but there not a thousand of them in Iowa.

The Monmouth University Poll was conducted by telephone from December 3 to 6, 2015 with
425 Iowa voters likely to attend the Republican presidential caucuses in February 2016. This sample has a
margin of error of +4.8 percent. The poll was conducted by the Monmouth University Polling Institute in
West Long Branch, NJ. Methodological note: This poll marks a slight modification in Monmouth’s sampling methodology for the Iowa Republican
caucuses. Prior sample frames included past state primary voters only. The current poll includes a small proportion (30%) of
regular general election voters. The addition of these voters did not have a significant impact on the overall findings. For
example, under the previous tighter sampling frame, Cruz’s support would be 25% compared to 24% in the full sample, Trump’s
support would be 16% rather than 19%, and Carson’s 13% support would be unchanged. Rubio’s support using the prior frame
would be slightly higher (21%) than in the current frame (17%). The current sample frame suggests a high-end turnout level of
approximately 140,000 caucusgoers. http://www.monmouth.edu/assets/0/32212254770/32212254991/32212254992/32212254994/32212254995/30064771087/de240398-df23-47b6-8470-91977d38b749.pdf Nice find by austerity http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/57909

“For the first time, I think the Trump phenomenon is becoming real,” a South Carolina Republican said.
“I do not think the media or the party establishment have a real grasp on how deep the anger and frustration is around the country,” that insider said when most recently surveyed last week. “After what have been ‘missteps’ by Trump in comparison of previous elections, he seems to have only strengthened. I still do not know if he can sustain it into the New Year — but after the Paris attacks, his stance on illegal immigration and unverified people coming into our nation has real impact.”
But his hold on Iowa and Nevada is more tenuous, according to insiders who note those states’ caucuses require significant organizational muscle to produce a win.
GOP insiders now have Cruz nudging Trump out of the lead in Iowa. That prediction came even before a Quinnipiac University poll this week showed the Texan running neck and neck with Trump. Neurosurgeon Ben Carson was the only other candidate to register significantly on this question. It’s the first time Cruz has led on this measure — after months of Trump and, briefly, Carson in front.
“I remain skeptical that Donald Trump's organization could turn out enough supporters today to win, and Ben Carson is fading on growing concerns that he's simply not up for the job,” said an Iowa Republican. “Cruz has been building — and continues to build — a solid organization. I'm not saying it won't change, although I've thought for some time now that Ted Cruz will win the Iowa caucuses — but this is the first week I'd put him on top in Iowa.” Still, the third of Iowa insiders who said Trump would win insisted he has built the campaign infrastructure to turn out his voters, even if they aren’t traditional caucus-goers. “Trump still has the best ground game and organization in the state,” one insider said. http://www.politico.com/story/2015/11/politico-caucus-donald-trump-iowa-2016-polling-216227

http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/nov/17/donald-trump-seen-unlikely-to-win-in-iowa-despite-/?page=all " . . .  Trump’s high poll numbers here are raising eyebrows among the state’s veteran politicos, who doubt he will be able to translate his appeal as a celebrity and political renegade into voters who show up to caucus on a cold February night. "It’s a potential problem of which Mr. Trump is aware. He’s hired some of the best Iowa operatives to try to figure out how to get supporters of his anti-establishment message, who may not be regular caucusgoers, to come out for him on Feb. 1. "But those on the ground say they’ll be surprised if he’s successful.  “I don’t know one Iowa caucusgoer who is going to show up for Trump on Feb. 1,” said Laura Kamienski, a Republican Party caucus precinct representative for Hiawatha District in Cedar Rapids. “The people who are answering the pollsters’ calls, I don’t know [if] they are the people who will turn out on caucus night.” "It’s happened before: Democrats Howard Dean in 2004 and Jesse Jackson in 1988 both had strong showings in the polls, but their supporters failed to materialize on caucus night, which is usually frigid, and involves showing up to spend several hours at a set time at a precinct site. "Mr. Trump draws supporters by the thousands to his rallies, but they are not the die-hard party activists who reliably turn out on caucus night. "Ms. Kamienski said she expects a surprise in the caucus this cycle similar to former Sen. Rick Santorum’s unexpected win in 2012.  . . .  "Mr. Trump’s appeal has also tested pollsters, who put a good deal of thought into trying to identify likely caucusgoers. Often that’s based on past voting history — but Mr. Trump is counting on new blood that’s tougher to evaluate. "Pollsters defended their survey methods and stood by their numbers. But some credited Mr. Trump’s dominance in polls to his near-universal name recognition . . . . "Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski dismissed any doubt about the poll numbers. He said it was coming from the same “political pundits who have been wrong every step of the way” about Mr. Trump’s candidacy, including predicting he would fade after the summer. “At which point will these elitists come around and wrap their heads around the fact that Donald Trump will be the nominee for the Republican Party?” said Mr. Lewandowski.  He also noted that they had hired the Iowa organizer from Mr. Santrorum’s 2012 campaign, Chuck Laudner, who is considered one of the most formidable grass-roots organizers and get-out-the-vote strategists in the state.
“You tell me another campaign who has the individual running it who won the last time. You can’t because we” have Mr. Laudner, he said, adding that the campaign also had the largest paid staff, with 13 operatives on the ground in Iowa. "Mr. Trump’s poll numbers have been impressive. The billionaire businessman has been at the front of the pack in Iowa and nationally most of the time since he entered the race, though he has traded the lead recently with retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson.
. . . 
“There are always candidates in the race who strike a chord but [who] people don’t see as a serious presidential candidate,” said David Yepsen, an expert on presidential campaigns in Iowa. “I’m thinking specifically of Jesse Jackson on the Democratic side. I saw lots of good Democrats show up at his events and cheer, but on caucus night they went someplace else.”
 . . . .
"Mr. Yepsen acknowledged that Mr. Trump’s tough talk on immigration, trade and national security resonates with voters in Iowa and across the country. But he said that might not be enough.“I just think you have to look like a president, you have to act like a president, and protest candidates, angry candidates ultimately don’t do very well because protest and anger are not presidential,” he said. “We expect our presidents to be upbeat and optimistic: Reagan, Roosevelt, John Kennedy. The hot populist, the angry candidate — Jesse Jackson, Pat Robertson, Ross Perot — they may appeal to people and they may get some votes, but on caucus night it is oftentimes cooler heads that prevail.” "He pointed to polls showing a large percentage of Iowa Republican caucusgoers saying they would never vote for Mr. Trump.  A Bloomberg Politics/Des Moines Register poll last month showed that 25 percent of likely Republican caucusgoers picked Mr. Trump as the candidate they would most like to see drop out of the race, the highest share of any candidate. "Craig Robinson, a former GOP operative who writes the Iowa Republican blog, said the pundits and the political activists had misjudged the energy and convictions of Mr. Trump’s supporters. “It’s wishful thinking from those people supporting traditional candidates, and I think they underestimate Trump a little bit,” said Mr. Robinson, who is not supporting a candidate in the race.

http://www.politico.com/story/2015/11/iowa-caucuses-republicans-2016-turnout-215496#ixzz3qmrCIWfw " Top Republican strategists are almost universally predicting a record-setting turnout at the 2016 Iowa caucuses, but there’s widespread disagreement between them over just how big turnout will be — and whether it will be high enough to lift political outsiders like Donald Trump or Ben Carson to victory. "Talk of turnout has been fueled by a 112-page Jeb Bush campaign document that leaked last week . . .[which] revealed that Bush’s campaign is modeling a turnout of 128,542 caucus-goers — a record, but a narrow one with only 7,000 more voters than voted in 2012. "Other Republicans believe the actual number will be tens of thousands higher — enough of a wave to wash away Bush and his establishment-oriented campaign. "With the early Republican primary debates shattering all TV audience records . . . there is a heated discussion among seasoned Iowa operatives about exactly how many of those who have tuned into the must-see reality TV series of the fall season will trudge through an cold winter night next February for a multi-hour caucus. "Three candidates are openly talking about expanding the usual electorate — Trump and Carson, with their nontraditional campaigns expressly aiming for first-time caucus-goers, and Rand Paul, who has focused heavily on mobilizing college-aged Iowans.Two past Iowa winners, Huckabee and Rick Santorum, are trying to reassemble their old statewide networks of religious supporters. Bush is bolstered by one of the biggest, if not the biggest, paid operations in the state. Ted Cruz already has county chairs in all 99 Iowa counties, as well as supportive pastors across the state. Marco Rubio is climbing in the polls. Chris Christie, who has campaigned aggressively in New Hampshire, is giving Iowa a fresh look amid Bush’s sinking poll numbers. . . . Plus, Bobby Jindal and Carly Fiorina, still struggling in the polls, have held among the most campaign stops in the state — a combined 200 this cycle, . . . . ". . . with 610,530 actively registered Republicans in the state, and the party accepting new registrations up until the caucus on February 1, the number could theoretically soar past even the highest projections. . . . We have 14, 15 candidates driving turnout. And each of those candidates attracts a different section of Iowa caucus-goers and, by the way, they’re all driving their own people. They’re identifying their own people.”
. . .
" Steve Grubbs, Paul’s chief Iowa strategist [said] “Maybe I’ve just become a cynic, but every four years we think, ‘Oh my gosh, this is going to be the one where just record numbers of people come out.’ ”
Then they don’t. “The reality is Republican primaries are very heavily senior citizen turnout,” Grubbs continued. “Going out when it’s dark and the coldest time of winter … It’s hard to get people out at night, black ice, the whole thing.” Asked about Paul’s emphasis on youth when the electorate skews so old, Grubbs added, “The good news for us is young people aren’t afraid of cold weather.” "Tim Albrecht, an Iowa adviser to the Bush campaign . . . said of overall turnout. “The best predictor of caucus turnout is whether or not a voter has caucused in the past.” "There have been dramatic swings in caucus turnout . . .  "With 15 candidates in the 2016 Republicans field, strategists are looking at the possibility of both record high turnout and a record-low percentage for the winner. No one has won the Iowa caucuses in the past 40 years with less than 25 percent of the vote, but campaigns are preparing for the possibility that the 2016 winner could fall well below that. "The Bush document, for instance, outlines a goal of a mere 18.45 percent of the vote, or 23,765 Iowans. I welcome any comments on how I arrived at this conclusion and on how it could be improved.
1) Polls are a prediction of an event if it were held today.  The problem is that this event is
four months away.  I had a bit of trouble in finding old polls, but I did find:
2012 Santorum won - but in Oct 2011 he was at 3% in Iowa.  2008 Huckabee won - in Oct 2007
he was tied for second at 13%.  I believe that Bush was leading at this stage in 2000 and went
on to win, but I think that his lead was larger than Trump's. 
2) I also looked at the Democrats to see what had happened - Obama won Iowa in 2008 and
was at 22% on October 2007.  Kerry won in 2004 and he was at 9% at this stage.  (I am simply
using it to see how indicative presidential polls are at this stage.)
3) Santorum with just 3% at this stage in 2012 has gone on to win Iowa.   So in looking at the RCP polls 
averages, I'll eliminate Pataki, Graham, Santorum, Christie, Gilmore, and Kasich as they are all polling 
below 3%.
4) That leaves nine - Trump, Carson, Fiorina, Cruz, Rubio, Bush, Huckabee, Jindal, and Paul.  
All things being equal 100 divided by 9 is an 11% chance.   Leads do mean something historically
so Trump has a better chance than someone polling much lower.  I think there is also a chance that someone 
(Paul?) will drop out of the race by then and/or fall further in the polls.   So I will give Trump 1 
out of 8 based on someone dropping out/falling further and a bump to 1 out of 6 based on his lead.

Probabilities: Trump 55%, Carson 30%, Cruz 5%, Fiorina 5%, Rubio 5% Are October polls predictive? In the 2008 and 2012 Republican caucuses, 2 of the top 3 finishers were also in the top 3 in the October polls. Romney and Huckabee (2008), and Romney and Paul (2012) were in the top 3 in both the October Iowa Caucus polls and the Iowa Caucus itself. Following the October polls, four candidates experienced big surges: Huckabee (21 points, 2nd to 1st) and Paul (11 points, 3rd) in 2008, and Santorum (20 points, 7th to 1st) and Gingrich in 2012. Gingrich's surge faded well before the Caucus. Those who lost big were Giuliani (11 points, 3rd to 6th) in 2008, and Cain (35 points, 1st to dropping out) in 2012. The other candidates' October poll numbers were actually quite similar to their vote percentage in the Caucus. Conclusions:
-Huckabee and Santorum won because they were the favorites of white evangelical voters.
-Allegations of misconduct in the personal and business life of Giuliani, Cain, and Gingrich accounts for their defeats.
-Currently, Trump and Carson are the favorites of evangelical and "very conservative" voters by a wide margin. Cruz, Fiorina, and Rubio have the potential to rise in the polls and stage an upset. But that probably won't happen unless either Trump or Carson faces some crisis that derails his campaign. Caucus dynamics are fascinating.   Thinking in print about how caucus dynamics would impact Trump . . .  Alaska is a caucus state.  I've participated.  

Caucusing is way more time-consuming than voting.  You have to block out at least half a day, maybe longer, in order to participate, and you can't just show up on the spur of the moment:  there are other meetings to go to first. So, who goes to the caucus?  
-basically, it's the party faithful and the passionate.  
-People who are selected by their precinct.   
    Some people are "pre-selected" to attend the caucus by virtue of their office as per the rules of the state's party.  
    Other caucus goers are elected or appointed on the precinct level, as per their state party rules. 
    So, a lot can depend on who goes to the precinct meetings. The candidate(s) with the best organization, who make sure that    
                precinct meetings are flooded with their supporters are most likely to have delegates to send to the caucus.
-Trump is thought to not have a very strong organization in Iowa (yet?), capable of identifying & rounding up enough people to attend precinct meetings and the caucus.
       The Republican party is not happy about Trump.
       My sense is that his support is as superficial as he:  people are not passionate enough about him to turn out for a caucus.
       So, Trump may have fewer people at the caucus than poll numbers might lead people to think he will. What happens at a caucus?  
-In Alaska, all the delegates gather, then "break out" into clusters: one cluster for each candidate.
-The people in each cluster are counted.  The people in the smallest cluster(s) are told to disband and join other clusters.
-Then the yelling and arm-twisting and cajoling and begging and arguing and deal-making begins.
-Some delegates move of their own accord into the group of their 2nd favorite candidate. 
-Other delegates move to the cluster of the strongest candidate who opposes the person they dislike the most. 
-Others are "persuaded"  . . . Caucus goers are offered incentives to switch with promises like, "We promise that 2 of you 
             will go to the national convention."
-Then counts are done again, and the smallest cluster(s) are told to disband and re-distribute themselves.
-This process can repeat itself several times, until it is clear that one candidate has a majority of the delegates at the caucus The situation is very fluid, very dynamic.  There are lots of decisions made on the spur of the moment.   The caucus system is biased towards the candidate with the strongest organization, the most passionate support, and the support of the party establishment. I don't think Trump has any of those 3 things (at least not at this point), so I'm reducing my forecast significantly.

Put another way, this year, candidates with the resources to play a good ground game may have a disadvantage precisely because they are able to command those resources. I've included data from the most recent poll I've found, which shows Trump leading still. On the other hand, this is a caucus, not an ordinary election. Source: Dateline 9-22-15 ...Donald Trump continuing to lead in the state with 24% to 17% for Ben Carson, and 13% for Carly Fiorina. In single digits but getting decent levels of support are Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio at 8%, Jeb Bush and Mike Huckabee at 6%, the now departed Scott Walker at 5%, and Bobby Jindal and Rand Paul at 4%. Rounding out the field are John Kasich at 2%, Chris Christie and Rick Santorum at 1%, and Lindsey Graham, Jim Gilmore, and George Pataki all at less than 1%. Trump's recent comments about President Obama waging a war on Christianity don't hurt him much with the GOP base. 69% agree with the sentiment that the President has waged a war on Christianity, with only 17% disagreeing. As the field consolidates, it won't consolidate around Trump. Also, for the last several cycles, the Republican Iowa caucus has been won by whichever candidate the evangelicals coalesce around.  Multiply divorced coastal Trump would seem to be on odd choice for that slice of the electorate.
It is fine until someone gets hurt. Trump is selling lots of popcorn, but don't think he has the credentials, policies or staying power to win Iowa (BTW, is a plurality winning?)

Lots of volatility; two republicans dropped out last week and four months is eons in the race. Still, Trump seems invulnerable to the gaffes and slip ups that would have befallen a less capable rodeo clown by now. His popularity is buoyed by a vocal minority that wants to "stick it to the fat cats" in Washington and they are the ones who tend to turn out for primaries. Fiorina's odds are good too if she can maintain this momentum. Almost all the other candidates are too bland or wedded to the establishment to pull off a victory here. Recall that in 2011, Santorum won the Iowa primary. Now, he polls in the margin of error. Cowboys poll hard early but burn out fast.

I'm going to stick with a slight NO, but will update soon.  Trump is really at a cusp right now... it's the first time he's lost any momentum in the public eye.   People have always predicted a shelf-life for his candidacy, but he's surprised them so far. But like any meme/fad, if it's not growing, it's probably dieing.  His candidacy is no different from tracking the dynamics of The Ice Bucket Challenge or Gangnam Style. In a few weeks, we'll know if he plunges down to single digits. Predicting the results of a presidential primary or caucus is not easy, even in the days leading up to it. If I remember correctly, the leader in the Iowa polls in late September usually has not gone on to win the caucus. Same goes with New Hampshire. However, I think this time might be one of the exceptions. First-tier:
-Trump 65%
-Carson 25% Race for third, but a surprise win by any of these candidates is possible:
-Cruz 5%
-Fiorina 2.5%
-Rubio 1.5%
-Jindal 1% Former winners of the Iowa Caucus who will wait until after Iowa to drop out:
-Huckabee 0%
-Santorum 0% Candidates for whom winning Iowa was never a possibility:
-Bush, Christie, Graham, Gilmore, Paul, Pataki, Kasich all 0% By the way, Trump has a real chance of winning the GOP nomination (~40%). Most of the pundits are still in denial about that.
